quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And we ended up renting a stadium to just hire 60,000 drivers in a couple of weeks.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete example of scrappy, high-leverage scaling tactics for rapid supply acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When I got there it was in a house and I realized I've probably made a huge mistake, but we were growing very quickly already, even at that small scale of 4,000 orders per day.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Highlights how early-stage companies can look chaotic while still showing strong growth signals worth betting on.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: To put this in context, Gojek completes more rights per day than Lyft and more food deliveries than GrubHub, Uber Eats and DoorDash combined, and it's the number one mobile wallet in Indonesia and Southeast Asia.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a striking scale comparison that challenges common assumptions about where the biggest consumer tech businesses are built.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In my opinion, American startups have a lot to learn from startups in Asia and Crystal has been at the ground floor of some of the biggest successes there.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian prompt to look outside the US for playbooks and lessons on building and scaling consumer products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, based on our data about a third of people will consider switching to another company after just one bad experience during onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A concrete retention risk data point that quantifies how costly onboarding failures can be.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So if your CSV importer doesn't work right, which is super common, considering customer files are chalked full of unexpected data and formatting, they'll leave.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: Highlights a common, practical failure mode (messy real-world data) and its direct impact on churn.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I've consistently seen that improving onboarding is one of the highest leverage opportunities for both signup conversion and increasing longterm retention, getting people to your aha moment more quickly and reliably is so incredibly important.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A high-leverage growth heuristic: prioritize onboarding improvements to accelerate time-to-value and boost conversion/retention.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's because flawless data onboarding acts like a catalyst to get them and their customers where they need to go, faster.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“catalyst”) for how reliable data import accelerates customer success and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Crystal’s nontraditional path into product and growth
quotes.text: I didn't realize people start looking for jobs before they'd graduate. So the last two weeks of school I was looking on Craigslist, because I was like, "Craigslist is how everyone gets a job." I'm a first generation American student, so my parents could not help me at all with like, "You should look into this company called McKinsey," or, "Here are all of the life paths that you have ahead of you."
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Highlights a scrappy, nontraditional job-search approach and the importance of self-directed career navigation without built-in networks.

quotes.topic_title: Crystal’s nontraditional path into product and growth
quotes.text: I ended up owning a huge Excel database of 130,000 rows, 60 plus columns. And because again, I am very impatient, I was like, "This is a terrible experience. How would I create a customer database?" And so I ended up Google fooling all of the work needed to build a MySQL database, I presented a plan, and investment banking, surprise, surprise, is not very tech forward.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete example of turning operational pain into a self-taught technical upgrade (Excel → database) and recognizing org constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Crystal’s nontraditional path into product and growth
quotes.text: So I did took the investment banking strategies that I had learned there and applied the same pattern matching to companies in Southeast Asia.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A transferable-methods mental model: reuse learned evaluation frameworks (“pattern matching”) in a new market/industry.

quotes.topic_title: Crystal’s nontraditional path into product and growth
quotes.text: I literally emailed someone after Googling HR at Gojek and said, "I'm willing to move to Indonesia, take a bet on me." And they actually did.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Actionable outreach tactic: cold email with a clear, high-commitment offer that reduces perceived hiring risk.

quotes.topic_title: Crystal’s nontraditional path into product and growth
quotes.text: Five years fly by insanely fast. I went through building out the data team from scratch. When you have all of the data, you know how much fraud you have in the system. So then I ended up building out the fraud and risk team, picked up performance marketing, and then it was like, okay, now we're ready to grow. So you have all of this data now take on growth.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A sequencing framework for scaling: data foundation → fraud/risk → performance marketing → growth.

quotes.topic_title: Gojek and Kumu scale, and super-app dynamics
quotes.text: So across Southeast Asia, we had about 170 million users. Southeast Asia has scale. If you ever wanted to work at scale, you would go to Southeast Asia.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point and a career heuristic for practitioners seeking high-scale product/growth experience.

quotes.topic_title: Gojek and Kumu scale, and super-app dynamics
quotes.text: We had 20 plus different services from transportation to food, shopping, medicine delivery, bill pay, movie tickets. So it was like all of the startups in America in one app, all being built at the same time with the same user base.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A vivid mental model for super-app dynamics and the compounding advantage of building multiple businesses on one shared user base.

quotes.topic_title: Gojek and Kumu scale, and super-app dynamics
quotes.text: So I think taking that Warren Buffet approach, I knew that the product made sense. The market made sense as well.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A practical decision framework for joining or betting on a startup: validate product and market fundamentals first.

quotes.topic_title: Gojek and Kumu scale, and super-app dynamics
quotes.text: And we ended up renting a stadium to just hire 60,000 drivers in a couple of weeks.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A specific, high-leverage growth/ops tactic showing how offline execution can unlock rapid marketplace supply scaling.

quotes.topic_title: Gojek and Kumu scale, and super-app dynamics
quotes.text: And so when your phone is full, are you going to delete a photo of your kid or are you going to delete this app? You're probably going to delete the app. So for anyone to really survive, it has to be part of this super app concept.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A counterintuitive explanation for why super apps thrive in mobile-first markets: device storage constraints drive consolidation.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy growth: doing things that don’t scale
quotes.text: So maybe there are some limitations there, but this concept of doing things that are somewhat crazy, but validate a point, doing stuff that don't scale, especially I think is really the bread and butter of what we did at Gojek. We were insanely scrappy.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A clear mental model for growth: prioritize scrappy, non-scalable actions that validate a hypothesis before investing in scalable systems.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy growth: doing things that don’t scale
quotes.text: We'll add a hundred drivers randomly to a WhatsApp group. We'll tell them, "Every time you are on a ride with a customer, try to sell them this pitch. You are the only driver who can sell a subscription package. Have the customer give you $10. Text us when they say yes. Someone will be sitting by this phone all day, every day.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete Wizard-of-Oz experiment design that uses existing channels (WhatsApp + humans) to test willingness-to-pay and conversion without building product.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy growth: doing things that don’t scale
quotes.text: It works. It's really this Wizard of Oz experience. We don't have to build anything.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that you can validate value props with manual ops before writing code.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy growth: doing things that don’t scale
quotes.text: So it's really just like, what is the user experience that we want to create? How do we manifest that as quickly as possible? Let's just try that first.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A practical methodology: start from the desired UX and prototype the fastest possible version to test behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappy growth: doing things that don’t scale
quotes.text: The only thing better than knowing... If you have data of what your customers are doing, that is the best data you could ever get.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A strong principle for early-stage teams: optimize for behavioral data over opinions when deciding what to build.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation at tiny sample sizes
quotes.text: You should. Even if you have a sample size of 30, the data you get back, generally, does not change but its precision will.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A contrarian argument for running experiments extremely early: small samples still reveal real directional trends, just with lower confidence.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation at tiny sample sizes
quotes.text: So mathematically speaking, you're going to get the same level of trends, but the precision at which you understand those trends will become more deep if you have more data.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A mental model for interpreting tiny-sample experiments: trends are informative even when precision is low.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation at tiny sample sizes
quotes.text: But what's better than having zero is definitely 30.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb that reframes early experimentation as strictly better than waiting for “enough data.”

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation at tiny sample sizes
quotes.text: So everyone wants to go on retention. They want to see that users are doing this thing, and they want to get from step zero to 100 really quickly, but they don't realize that users make decisions based on succeeding events.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A framework shift from optimizing retention directly to mapping the sequence of user decisions and prerequisites that drive it.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation at tiny sample sizes
quotes.text: And we did find that when we told people, "This friend purchased from this merchant," you would be twice as likely to purchase from a brand new restaurant then users who did not have this feature.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete example and data point showing how solving a preceding barrier (trust) can unlock conversion and downstream retention.

quotes.topic_title: Retention and conversion: what to optimize and why
quotes.text: But in reality it was really when you think about retention, that's just not specific enough.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Reframes “retention” as an overly broad goal and pushes teams to define more concrete, actionable levers.

quotes.topic_title: Retention and conversion: what to optimize and why
quotes.text: It's usually the step right before conversion.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for where to focus retention work: fix the pre-conversion bottleneck to lift downstream retention.

quotes.topic_title: Retention and conversion: what to optimize and why
quotes.text: They haven't even experienced the product, it's clearly not the product that's wrong.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Counterintuitive diagnosis: if users bounce before first action, the issue is often messaging/positioning (copy), not core product.

quotes.topic_title: Retention and conversion: what to optimize and why
quotes.text: So users who eventually check out or eventually completed the aha moment, what are the user paths, and what is the longest one that seems like it's the most painful?
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete method for growth work: analyze paths of eventual converters and shorten the most painful, longest journey.

quotes.topic_title: Retention and conversion: what to optimize and why
quotes.text: Conversion rates go from 60% to 90% over the course of a few weeks of just optimizing that and putting more content there.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Specific example showing how fixing a high-intent bottleneck (slow, underutilized search) can produce major conversion gains quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Growth strategy framework: physics, constraints, and loops
quotes.text: So step one is, what are the physics?
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A simple framing for modeling growth by first defining the immutable realities of your market/product/model/channels.

quotes.topic_title: Growth strategy framework: physics, constraints, and loops
quotes.text: So we would always change one small thing at a time and make sure that it fit into the model.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Practical advice to reduce risk in growth bets by isolating variables and avoiding multi-parameter changes.

quotes.topic_title: Growth strategy framework: physics, constraints, and loops
quotes.text: And word of mouth actually was primarily driven by, "I saw a driver on the street, so I knew Gojek was here."
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Counterintuitive acquisition insight: offline visibility can be the primary driver of “word of mouth.”

quotes.topic_title: Growth strategy framework: physics, constraints, and loops
quotes.text: You wouldn't believe how great of a salesperson someone can be when you were literally trapped in a car with them going somewhere.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Memorable example of turning an existing supply-side asset (drivers) into a high-leverage sales channel via captive attention.

quotes.topic_title: Growth strategy framework: physics, constraints, and loops
quotes.text: It was huge. It was 60% of acquisition once we released that.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Concrete data point showing the scale of impact from using drivers to drive GoPay adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern growth team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a common structural gap in growth tooling that creates friction and slows experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to waste of time building internal tools or trying to run your experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable warning about the hidden costs of poor experimentation infrastructure and mismatched tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved about our experimentation platform was being able to easily slice results by device, by country and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of a practical analysis workflow (segmentation) that helps teams find what’s really driving results.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic clickthrough metrics and instead uses our north star metrics like activation, retention, subscriptions and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Encourages a measurement model shift from shallow proxy metrics to business-meaningful north-star outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the framework to Kumu’s social product
quotes.text: With Gojek you knew if you got the job done. You made a transaction. With Kumu, how do you know if a consumer made a friend, felt like they had a genuine friendship?
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Highlights the measurement challenge in social products where success is emotional/implicit rather than transactional and explicit.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the framework to Kumu’s social product
quotes.text: So you almost have to create more friction to identify users who really got past that barrier and aren't explicit with the activity that they did.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Counterintuitive growth/measurement tactic: add friction to surface high-intent users and meaningful progress signals.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the framework to Kumu’s social product
quotes.text: So we almost create this artificial friction to help differentiate how deeply a user wants something or needs something.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A practical methodology for intent segmentation: use deliberate hurdles to distinguish casual users from those seeking the core job-to-be-done.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the framework to Kumu’s social product
quotes.text: Do they fill out the form? Do they fill out a questionnaire of many questions? Do they go through this friction just to get access to a community?
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Concrete examples of “intentional friction” instruments teams can implement to identify meaningful user paths.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the framework to Kumu’s social product
quotes.text: We leave a lot of breadcrumbs in the app to be able to identify those paths.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Encapsulates an approach to measuring social growth by instrumenting user journeys with observable signals (“breadcrumbs”).

quotes.topic_title: Big growth unlocks: copy, familiarity, and churn reduction
quotes.text: Definitely, in the early days it was copy. So I think if your product does something that's not super familiar, you have to tie it to something that is.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A practical growth principle: use familiar mental models in messaging when introducing an unfamiliar product concept.

quotes.topic_title: Big growth unlocks: copy, familiarity, and churn reduction
quotes.text: Before that, one thing that we did was to actually take someone's virtual account number and put it onto a picture of a credit card. You know what a credit card is, that's familiar to you. A lot of people didn't know what a digital wallet was.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete example of translating an unfamiliar product (digital wallet) into a familiar artifact (credit card) to drive comprehension and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Big growth unlocks: copy, familiarity, and churn reduction
quotes.text: And we actually saw top ups increase based on us, literally just sending that picture with someone's virtual account number there.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A specific outcome showing that small copy/UX changes can measurably move a key growth metric.

quotes.topic_title: Big growth unlocks: copy, familiarity, and churn reduction
quotes.text: Because canceling the subscription is a permanent solution to having too much fear. How do you make a temporary solution that solves the actual problem? Adding in a pause button actually helped alleviate a lot of the churn that was becoming very hard to reacquire back.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A churn-reduction tactic: replace irreversible cancellation with a reversible “pause” that matches the user’s underlying need.

quotes.topic_title: Big growth unlocks: copy, familiarity, and churn reduction
quotes.text: We'll just solve the problem at that small constraint where everyone drops off.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A constraint-focused methodology: prioritize fixing the highest-friction drop-off point instead of adding broader, more complex initiatives.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: insights vs measurements
quotes.text: Do not treat metric gathering as entertainment. It's not there for you to be like, "Oh, that's interesting, how novel," and then not act on it. So real news is information that changes what you do in the real world. And if you don't change what you're doing, what you are doing is just getting entertainment.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A sharp mental model for judging whether dashboards are driving decisions or just passive consumption.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: insights vs measurements
quotes.text: The next step in instrumentation is to look at the fact that measurements do not equate to insights. A measurement would be an observation. It's a data point in your database.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A clear distinction practitioners can use to separate raw metrics from decision-grade insights.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: insights vs measurements
quotes.text: So the insight will provide value when you have this, why answered? Why is this person doing this thing? Here's why. And then you are going to act differently.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Defines “insight” as explanatory and behavior-changing, not merely descriptive.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: insights vs measurements
quotes.text: The insight is instrumenting properties into an event so that you can segment who is doing what behavior and make some hypotheses on that observation. Test that hypothesis, and then you get some causal representation of whether or not that hypothesis was right.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A practical methodology for turning tracking into segmentation, hypotheses, and experiments that validate causality.

quotes.topic_title: Why analytics efforts fail: insights vs measurements
quotes.text: And that actually tells you how to change your marketing approach. It tells you in what circumstances does someone do this. When it's a high GMV basket, give power users the ability to get a free discount, but do not do this for non-powered users because they won't convert any better than they normally would.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete example of segmentation turning an observation into an actionable marketing decision.

quotes.topic_title: Instrumentation quality: event properties and context
quotes.text: So I already know if a team is good at instrumentation or not just by looking at the instrumentation spec.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: you can assess instrumentation maturity before looking at dashboards by reviewing the spec itself.

quotes.topic_title: Instrumentation quality: event properties and context
quotes.text: The symptom of a bad data tracking approach is you have a ton of rows with a ton of events, but every event has one property or no property being tracked.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A clear diagnostic for bad tracking that teams can immediately audit in their event schema.

quotes.topic_title: Instrumentation quality: event properties and context
quotes.text: And the properties there should be things like how many drivers do they see on the screen? What is the pickup location? What city is it in? What latitude and longitude is it? Is there surge pricing? What is the current minimum fare? Do they have a voucher code?
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A concrete example of “good instrumentation” capturing experience context, not just button clicks.

quotes.topic_title: Instrumentation quality: event properties and context
quotes.text: Being able to do the second layer approach of the why and not just stop at, "That's weird. When you have two drivers you are less likely to book." But then you never ask why. That drives me crazy.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A memorable push to go beyond correlation and instrument for causal drivers behind user behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Instrumentation quality: event properties and context
quotes.text: If I were to press this button, why would I and why would I not? And am I tracking that in my user properties? So it's really just sitting down and mapping out the experience.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A simple methodology for designing event taxonomies by mapping user decisions and motivations.

quotes.topic_title: Recommended analytics stack by company stage
quotes.text: That really depends on how early they are.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Sets a stage-based decision framework for choosing an analytics stack rather than defaulting to one “best” toolset.

quotes.topic_title: Recommended analytics stack by company stage
quotes.text: So if they have a single data warehouse with all of their transactional data, usually I say, you can probably get by with Google Data Studio. It's free usually with whatever you're using.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Actionable advice to start with lightweight, low-cost dashboards when data is centralized and needs are simple.

quotes.topic_title: Recommended analytics stack by company stage
quotes.text: If you need in app mobile device event tracking, I usually recommend CleverTap because Mixpanel has unfortunately failed me a lot. And Amplitude doesn't have the CRM components that I would need all in one space.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A tool choice grounded in real-world reliability and product gaps, challenging the default assumption that Mixpanel/Amplitude are always sufficient.

quotes.topic_title: Recommended analytics stack by company stage
quotes.text: Then I would get into Segment.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Clear escalation point: when you need more piping/less ETL, add a CDP layer to scale analytics operations.

quotes.topic_title: Recommended analytics stack by company stage
quotes.text: So I usually look at something like Eppo to just automate the decision making flow.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Practical methodology for experimentation maturity: use tooling to standardize and speed up experiment decisions rather than building bespoke dashboards.

quotes.topic_title: How to set up and evolve a growth team
quotes.text: So we didn't really know what growth was at that time, but we knew there were obvious gaps to fill.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Defines an early-stage growth team as a pragmatic gap-filling function rather than a fully formed discipline.

quotes.topic_title: How to set up and evolve a growth team
quotes.text: So things like figuring out what SMS provider we should use to send the OTP to this user who is signing up from this telco provider. That was a growth objective that isn't necessarily core feature work, but was a gap to fill given the onboarding and SMS success delivery rates.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Concrete example of growth work focused on removing onboarding friction via operational/technical levers (OTP delivery).

quotes.topic_title: How to set up and evolve a growth team
quotes.text: So it was all of these small acquisition, adoption and engagement use cases that growth was filling the gap on.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: A crisp scope statement for growth: targeted fixes across the funnel where core product teams aren’t covering key user problems.

quotes.topic_title: How to set up and evolve a growth team
quotes.text: Exactly. I think it's just setting the bar too high to expect someone to come in and model everything.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Pushes back on the common expectation that the first growth hire should define the entire growth model from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: How to set up and evolve a growth team
quotes.text: So it's really about having someone who already has all of this data knows where the biggest gaps are. Doesn't have to start from scratch and figure this out and then just picks some small space to work on that they know is workable.
quotes.speaker: Crystal Widjaja
quotes.context: Actionable hiring/operating advice: start growth by assigning a known, high-leverage gap and a narrow, workable scope.
